72F69740BB2B4D00AA0FDCDB43BDFC0B.description: Critique the statement: “You can determine the sample space for an event by carrying out an experiment.

28DD584F51174087B9BD72E89D439BE0.description: Explain how theoretical and experimental probabilities are related.

CD1399397AEB45149DAD69CD884DDF04.description: Compare the results of a probability experiment to the expected theoretical probabilities.

6BD7333ADD6541C2A08E4EBFE2E35A2C.description: Predict the likelihood of a specific outcome occurring in a probability experiment by determining the theoretical probability for the outcome and explain the reasoning.

0F5940CB75CD418486639C0D534130B7.description: Explore and describe examples of the use and importance of probability in traditional and modern games of First Nations and Métis peoples.

752128893FE74D649FC34D3B6E4B44B8.description: Explain what a probability of 1 for a specific outcome means by providing an example.

9BE9FA595B934D6885398F427299E8F3.description: Explain what a probability of 0 for a specific outcome means by providing an example.

FA60F1DC134845628F2F36998C68E07E.description: List the sample space (possible outcomes) for an event (such as the tossing of a coin, rolling of a die with 10 sides, spinning a spinner with five sections, random selection of a classmate for a special activity, or guessing a hidden quantity) and explain the reasoning.

2A38B971DCE24EB4931E513B06BB7458.description: Observe situations relevant to self, family, or community where probabilities are stated and/or used to make decisions.

266102608B884D74B28E53B94ED5E5E5.description: Demonstrate understanding of probability by: determining sample space, differentiating between experimental and theoretical probability, determining the theoretical probability, determining the experimental probability and comparing experimental and theoretical probabilities

AF8578D221674620B2E8FD29C79D452E.description: Justify the selection of a type of graph for a set of data collected through questionnaires, experiments, databases, or electronic media

D839DC4BAAD64471AAB56B9A374A5083.description: Answer a self-generated question using databases or electronic media to collect data, then graphing and interpreting the data to draw a conclusion

A28D997895CA4624A3960EC2A6F3B769.description: Answer a self-generated question by performing an experiment, recording the results, graphing the data, and drawing a conclusion

F9B9A06D0E4A4D3FACB247DAABE0F9ED.description: Select a method for collecting data to answer a given question and justify the choice.

1B1CFE5864C34851896E04BC9A5C26D5.description: Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or community in which data might be collected through questionnaires, experiments, databases, or electronic media.

815504D377C649F9A8BD64D8E8DEF3EA.description: Interpret (through interpolation and extrapolation) the line graph or graphs of discrete data points for a situation to make decisions or solve problems.

CE1A2265E4194C1D9D211734312780FA.description: Construct a graph (line graph or a graph of discrete data points) to represent data given in a table for a particular situation.

02687C82EC2C40E3BEE4514A65D25635.description: Describe patterns seen in a given line graph or a graph of discrete data points, and describe a situation that the graph might represent.

B79A117EBC7B43279AC55B68C4E965FA.description: Determine whether a set of data should be represented by a line graph (continuous data) or a series of points (discrete data) and explain why.

F99C1D84C1C14E55B4DAE6C4A0536B1C.description: Explain the importance of accurate labelling of line graphs.

F07D11D0971845E197C2BCDF2FB22657.description: Extend understanding of data analysis to include: line graphs, graphs of discrete data, data collection through questionnaires, experiments, databases, and electronic media and interpolation and extrapolation.

8C0FA2A3E39447D2B92E5FDB2E7C07DB.description: Statistics and Probability - Goals: Spatial Sense, Number Sense, Logical Thinking, Mathematics as a Human Endeavour

44A201C313F54265BF5A0309840FA7A8.description: Describe a transformation of a 2-D shape shown in the first quadrant of the Cartesian plane that would result in the image of the 2-D shape also being in the first quadrant.

131BB01ED5C84D74BC3E9951A1ECC446.description: Perform a transformation on a given 2-D shape and identify the coordinates of the vertices of the image (limited to the first quadrant).

628A18E1339B4A5ABBF18BB31D992B15.description: Identify the coordinates of the vertices of a given 2-D shape (limited to the first quadrant of the Cartesian plane).

41842F1F0AE04984ACD4439EC696C245.description: Describe the creation and use of single and multiple transformations in First Nations and Métis lifestyles (e.g., birch bark biting).

E567315A428F4B30A63D3532032959DD.description: Create a design using the transformation of two or more 2-D shapes and write, or record orally, instructions that could be followed to reproduce the design.

85695E9601B342D191EA03A3319D5B8F.description: Analyze a given design created by transforming one or more 2-D shapes, and identify the original shape(s) and the transformations used to create the design.

C07A2A31E31E413EA18A4B0812B0E3BC.description: Identify designs within situations relevant to self, family, or community that could be described in terms of transformations of one or more 2-D shapes

75406450FFB94696825D8465ABDA588E.description: Verify whether or not a given set of transformations would transform a given 2-D shape into a given image.

70A49C241D0848E3B3D11CF4F90600A6.description: Describe a set of transformations, that when applied to a given 2-D shape, would result in a given image.

B241A2ECF1F24E85A85ABAABE0E42637.description: Determine the resulting image of applying a series of transformations upon a 2-D shape.

20D6FA543B1E4255935CDDBADA9AB500.description: Analyze 2-D shapes and their respective transformations to determine if the original shapes and their transformed images are congruent.

BEF2D372B7C14C1C9AA594F3228F801E.description: Model the translation, rotation, or reflection of 2-D shapes

77683050986546F0A427BB59C661DE96.description: Observe and classify different transformations found in situations relevant to self, family, or community.

0D3FDE82ED55427FB84CB1F2D8F91158.description: Demonstrate understanding of single, and combinations of, transformations of 2-D shapes (with and without the use of technology) including: identifying, describing and performing

18ABDEBD90DE450B8B5D49F3266860DD.description: Generalize and apply strategies for determining the distance between pairs of points on the same horizontal or vertical line.

5DDACB9ED549484EAFA213324E2A3149.description: Create a design in the first quadrant of the Cartesian plane, identify the coordinates of points on the design, and write or record orally directions for recreating the design.

A0F6F3563B504834BF100F586AE89015.description: Explain how to plot points on the Cartesian plane given the scale to be used on the axes (by 1, 2, 5, or 10).

573133EDD8C84F8F957126EB051246D8.description: Analyze the coordinates of the ordered pairs of points that lie on the vertical axis and generalize a strategy for identifying the ordered pairs of points on the vertical axis without plotting them

7486531C0D3D492189D964A89C49C79D.description: Analyze the coordinates of the ordered pairs of points that lie on the horizontal axis and generalize a strategy for identifying the ordered pairs of points on the horizontal axis without plotting them.

9D495542441346D8BB79A13B0C2914DB.description: Plot a point in the first quadrant of the Cartesian plane given its ordered pair

E0A54D5350D24717B2679B22EA28C83E.description: Explain why the axes of the Cartesian plane should be labelled.

25F42DB1C12E4252ABCB55370109A2D6.description: Demonstrate understanding of the first quadrant of the Cartesian plane and ordered pairs with whole number coordinates.

3B02FD602FA943A4A90F737668C28141.description: Replicate a polygon in a different orientation and informally prove that the new polygon is congruent and explain the reasoning.

D56C0FD250BD485B86F898195D768D57.description: Draw and classify examples of different types of triangles (scalene, isosceles, equilateral, right, obtuse, and acute) and explain the reasoning.

AC4AF84B172D4F1E83B9DE9BC1AD76D8.description: Critique the following statement: “When viewed from different perspectives, the same triangle can be classified in different ways.”

7E4102F61097417A921D73393AB3813F.description: Analyze a set of regular polygons and a set of irregular polygons to identify the characteristics of regular polygons.

A2386406E286407C955EBED09FE3DBF0.description: Compare two regular polygons (using superimposing or measuring) to determine whether or not the two polygons are congruent.

B6D1DD3D8DD64AE2BAC72F91725F201A.description: Analyze the types of triangles (scalene, isosceles, equilateral, right, obtuse, and acute) to determine which, if any, represent regular polygons.

5B507A25D0154F94B77A12C9130CB5D0.description: Observe examples of polygons, including triangles, found in situations relevant to self, family, or community and sort the polygons into irregular and regular polygons.

54C07E90B4794BB59E328DF60E74B759.description: Demonstrate understanding of regular and irregular polygons including: classifying types of triangles, comparing side lengths, comparing angle measures and differentiating between regular and irregular polygons • analyzing for congruence.

F9679648C64B493FB006B1EDAF24A061.description: Critique the following statements using concrete or pictorial models: “For any two right rectangular prisms, the one with the greater volume will be the prism that has the greatest base area”. and “For any two rectangles, the rectangle with the greatest perimeter will also have the greatest area”

AFBDD909AEDA421A9E618E49BD81EB80.description: Solve a situational question involving the perimeter of polygons, the area of rectangles, and/or the volume of right rectangular prisms.

FB479DE7D3D24346A09547AC542944BD.description: Analyze the effect of orientation on the perimeter of polygons, area of rectangles, and volume of right rectangular prisms.

ACF5CC2D0F424F679531A25C3834AB61.description: Generalize a rule (formula) for determining the volume of right rectangular prisms.

07169792E86A467AB40ADBA6966BCAD7.description: Explain, using models, the relationship between the area of the base of a right rectangular prism and the volume of the same 3-D object.

EA6C0292F4DB4CEE9D2DF8E240727834.description: Generalize a formula for determining the area of rectangles.

6BA442E57A074311A2F0AE630749C537.description: Generalize formulae and strategies for determining the perimeter of polygons, including rectangles and squares.

BC7446FEAB75477FAFCC8FD554FA9EAB.description: Extend and apply understanding of perimeter of polygons, area of rectangles, and volume of right rectangular prisms (concretely, pictorially, and symbolically) including: relating area to volume, comparing perimeter and area, comparing area and volume, generalizing strategies and formulae, analyzing the effect of orientation and solving situational questions.

E2EFC9D126634F9A9BC18CA2E717BD83.description: Solve situational questions involving angles in triangles and quadrilaterals.

DB15FF9A96BD49AEB75FD2FF352FC513.description: Provide a visual, concrete, and/or oral informal proof for the sum of the measures of the angles in a quadrilateral being 360° (assuming that the sum of the measures of the angles in a triangle is 180°).

7ED0396D7E61438DB81998FD6E928ADE.description: Generalize a relationship for the sum of the measures of the angles in any quadrilateral.

8D3FA65C655B4BE9836B12AA6CC23155.description: Generalize a relationship for the sum of the measures of the angles in any triangle.

8E46326C85E74A799F5C23AD7575E0DA.description: Describe and provide examples for different uses of angles, such as the amount of rotation or as the angle of opening between two sides of a polygon.

2519B3457F4A4840B7EC19CD90DB8C61.description: Measure angles in different orientations using a protractor.

4A79995DF51F41CE978F6DA78732EAAC.description: Describe how measuring an angle is different from measuring a length.

8784F8EC3F4E4B868459466D9419642A.description: Identify referents for angles of 45°, 90°, and 180° and use the referents to approximate the measure of other angles and to classify the angles as acute, obtuse, straight, or reflex.

DAEC80F06B5D462E9398BD1078B41B3E.description: Describe and apply strategies for sketching angles including 0°, 22.5°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 90°, 180°, 270°, and 360°.

51C8391265D24E4187633890C9CAA40C.description: Explore and present how First Nations and Métis peoples, past and present, measure, represent, and use angles in their lifestyles and worldviews.

173B74634F8241E9AE8E76DE5125111D.description: Observe, and sort by approximate measure, a set of angles relevant to self, family, or community.

C5BD7CA822334253B5B93021D35F64AD.description: Demonstrate understanding of angles including: identifying examples, classifying angles, estimating the measure, determining angle measures in degrees, drawing angles and applying angle relationships in triangles and quadrilaterals

3486E326B2F543EE984CCB8C7933F532.description: Shape and Space - Goals: Spatial Sense, Logical Thinking, Number Sense, Mathematics as a Human Endeavour

77C1F382F43745F49A7006428FCFABBD.description: Provide examples to explain the difference between an expression and an equation, both in terms of what each looks like and what each means.

85BB86E5771F48A38777A97712966A0B.description: Generalize an expression or equation that describes the rule for a pattern (e.g., the expression 4d or the equation 2n + 1 = 8).

7862A407C3FC477CB8DE82261C06DBFC.description: Write an equation to represent a table of values.

CACC3D346D7B4417A22176DC6E5C4CE0.description: Generalize an expression that describes the relationship between the two columns in a table of values.

E47742976A3C452385CC89041136783E.description: Develop and justify equations using letter variables that illustrate the commutative property of addition and multiplication (e.g., a + b = b + a or a × b = b × a).

55A29BBA7D7E4B66940754B4E0E3E1EE.description: Describe and represent geometric patterns and relationships relevant to First Nations and Métis peoples and explain how those patterns or relationships could be represented mathematically.

F733EFAAE9EC45D78CE47BD4B9894667.description: Analyze patterns arising from the determination of area of rectangles and generalize an equation describing a formula for the area of all rectangles.

85482307E3C14EC2A0338420809A1110.description: Analyze patterns arising from the determination of perimeter of rectangles and generalize an equation describing a formula for the perimeter of all rectangles.

FCE49EAF043F47C3A4F59D863398F7E0.description: Extend understanding of patterns and relationships by using expressions and equations involving variables.

052D50883E1E422F9D53EBDA9998D93D.description: Create, and record symbolically, equivalent forms of an equation by applying the preservation of equality (of a single operation) and verify the results concretely or pictorially (e.g., 3b = 12 is the same as 3b + 5 = 12 + 5 or 2r = 7 is the same as 3(2r) = 3(7)).

698F16493C034DE9A11CAC51E502A570.description: Model, and explain orally, the preservation of equality for addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division concretely (e.g., balances), pictorially, or physically.

0698A2B4F61D46B69427DCDA9072C8C2.description: Extend understanding of preservation of equality concretely, pictorially, physically, and symbolically.

5C9856C6A72E4E59AC5534AB3BA7F4D1.description: Research a current or past topic of interest relevant to First Nations and Métis peoples and present the data as a table of values or a graph.

D6C098DD0D28479BBB56D6C874AD9E2E.description: Describe a situation that could be represented by a given graph (limited to linear relations with discrete elements).

11F17D215B964F148346E8CCF0489270.description: Describe, using everyday language (orally or in writing), the relationship shown on a graph (limited to linear relations with discrete elements).

CB7AB6487525453183ED77136E1C81E5.description: Identify errors in the matching of graphs and tables of values and explain the reasoning.

F698A09AA5984F34B46EC46DAC39831A.description: Describe how a graph and a table of values are related.

FFCB90BFE8684087B2B5F0FCD6D13EF0.description: Translate a concrete, visual, or physical pattern into a table of values and a graph (limit graphs to linear relations with discrete elements).

855176CDE30E41D4931D640CBD864B5B.description: Analyze patterns in a table of values to solve a given situational question.

AB0AD45279634E00990ED9121B3CDE82.description: Create a table of values for a given equation.

3E3FC2CA17784B3DAF2F4F55EBD82BDA.description: Analyze the relationship between the two columns in a table of values and describe the relationship orally and symbolically.

1DBFDFCE0707439D9AEF8348A3DDE893.description: Analyze the relationship between consecutive values within each of the columns in a table of values and describe the relationship orally and symbolically

A7E1C36C46054CE2A3646594F59BD6CA.description: Determine missing values and correct errors found within a table of values and describe the strategy used.

EB9D6E09BF984408BC834EC34E485BEF.description: Create a table of values to represent a concrete or visual pattern.

1778BBD3DBC340818959F51AFE4C9B0D.description: Create and describe a concrete or visual model of a table of values.

A3CAD2E52F0E4735BB84C1E448813929.description: Extend understanding of patterns and relationships in tables of values and graphs.

100A61100FAB46F0923CD84FC8949931.description: Patterns and Relationships - Goals: Number Sense, Spatial Sense, Logical Thinking, Mathematics as a Human Endeavour

9635579C59CA4146A01055BB9449E22D.description: Communicate to others concretely, pictorially, orally, visually, physically, and/or in writing, what has been learned about the envisioning, representing, and use of quantity by First Nations and Métis peoples and how these understandings parallel, differ from, and enhance one’s own mathematical understandings about numbers.

2D91A1034CED44258E9322CF8D89B980.description: Compare the significance, representation, and use of quantity for different First Nations, Métis peoples, and other cultures.

D38AD7B8D00C49F492D4D5C5FC49A621.description: Gather and document information regarding the significance and use of quantity for at least one First Nation or Métis peoples from a variety of sources such as Elders and traditional knowledge keepers.

E08D559E03DE4379B79849A55D906597.description: Research and present how First Nations and Métis peoples, past and present, envision, represent, and use quantity in their lifestyles and worldviews.

C16D58419BCF4E579E353602831FB59C.description: Solve situational questions involving ratios (e.g., the ratio of students from a Grade 6 class going to a movie this weekend to those not going to a movie is 15:8. How many students are likely in the class and why?)

E233CC68FF114BF09B9DDECD81749E07.description: Describe a situation in which a ratio (given in colon, word, or fractional form) might occur.

2DBB96FEB8ED4C78B17E19A94BC6DEA1.description: Express a ratio in colon and word form.

BD3707C9383949FAB4516A8249395B50.description: Create representations of and compare part/whole and part/ part ratios (e.g., from a group of 3 boys and 5 girls, compare the representations boys to girls, boys to entire group, and girls to entire group – 3:5, 3:8, and 5:8 respectively).

48FC45DF3AC642588135DDE55FA47BDB.description: Critique the statement “Ratios and fractions are the same thing”.

CB6EB80D55334EC2894560C9477E70A7.description: Observe situations relevant to self, family, or community which could be described using a ratio, write the ratio, and explain what the ratio means in that situation.

90FD71FF1EA74C5B8A2196AFF2301F35.description: Demonstrate an understanding of ratio concretely, pictorially, and symbolically.

14BF473718F84779839BDF49876F0EEB.description: Respond to the question “Can quantities less than 1 be represented by a mixed number or improper fraction?”.

4533943E643543B0AAA5EE7DF1D98D45.description: Place a set of fractions, including whole numbers, mixed numbers, and improper fractions, on a number line and explain strategies used to determine position.

030B44FFCD5D4051A4DD3F874EBDD6EB.description: Explain the meaning of a given improper fraction or mixed number by setting it into a situation.

CB44ABD891944EECAF6070884EA5DEEB.description: Explain, with the use of concrete or visual representations, how to express an improper fraction as a mixed number (and vice versa) and write the resulting equality in symbolic form.

B96D490D7729458688EB80011639A6A6.description: Demonstrate, concretely, pictorially, or physically, how an improper fraction and a mixed number can be used to represent the same quantity.

363C60ADD2A04F0593C5BDDE771E606E.description: Observe and describe situations relevant to self, family, or community in which quantities greater than a whole, but which are not whole numbers, occur and describe those situations using either an improper fraction or a mixed number.

094EF10C16AF480F8A2D138430116AFF.description: Extend understanding of fractions to improper fractions and mixed numbers.

A295AA724863494787ECC5F79F4B6156.description: Explain the role of zero within integers and how it is different from other integers.

798AD45B3A8D4BECBA01A69817396A29.description: Extend a given number line by adding numbers less than zero and explain the pattern on each side of zero.

46B7B82C03154219B0F5A54BC819F9E4.description: Identify and correct errors in the ordering of integers on a number line.

575F381440764CEBAB07150B16DDF031.description: Order a set of integers in increasing or decreasing order and explain the reasoning used.

07E0595625BC4D8F89273A6B13E92A4D.description: Represent integers concretely, pictorially, or physically.

BB078B9B097346E68274D65B77A3C266.description: Compare two integers and describe their relationship symbolically using <, >, or =.

61C8DF34C8BD415AB1C9441E8240E14C.description: Observe and describe examples of integers relevant to self, family, or community and explain the meaning of those quantities within the contexts they are found.

142F4A70296643D0AB30D6CACE985442.description: Explore and explain the representation and meaning of negative quantities in First Nations and Métis peoples, past and present.

CD693A85612A446E856462AFCD688393.description: Demonstrate understanding of integers concretely, pictorially, and symbolically.

A134D7F1D17645D682E30BC144DA64AC.description: Describe a situation in which 0% or 100% might be stated.

05634E172D1E4DB9AF4A8BE150E4BDE2.description: Write the percent modeled within a concrete or pictorial representation.

FFC323E38C5B4D7BB9E8BB68080A785B.description: Create and explain representations (concrete, visual, or both) that establish relationships between whole number percents to 100, fractions, and decimals

41E47CB78AE94CF2911CAECB8947599E.description: Solve situational questions, and provide justification for possible decisions, using whole-numbered percents to 100.

50C98D9B9E6B4872879A17FE66EF8B42.description: Observe and describe examples of percents (whole numbered to 100) relevant to self, family, or community, represent the percent concretely or pictorially (possibly physically), and explain what the percent tells about the context in which it is being used.

6A8078BB48A34D53A705228E90661C2E.description: Demonstrate understanding of percent (limited to whole numbers to 100) concretely, pictorially, and symbolically

C3616046A7BD428BB552E57D6EF4834F.description: Solve a given situational question that involves multiplication and division of decimals, using multipliers from 0 to 9 and divisors from 1 to 9.

BE2FF52DF4FB4FD4AD8C59257CEF2F61.description: Develop a generalization about the impact on overall quantity when a decimal number is divided by a whole number

DDA1CDBC670943BEB118063EB1D7453D.description: Develop a generalization about the impact on overall quantity when multiplied by a decimal number between 0 and 1.

6F75DBF24E1744FD8433DA9984247CF1.description: Estimate products and quotients involving decimals.

97DBCC6841FB4ACD90398C0D561F655C.description: Explain, with justification, where the decimal place should be placed in the solution of a division statement.

211F00C13FFE4B94B114FEA0C33E6694.description: Explain, with justification, where the decimal place should be placed in the solution of a multiplication statement.

0FD8359D20714B7D8C78D40CA8D639C8.description: Observe and describe situations in which multiplication and division of decimals would occur.

89EE29F83ADB4AB0A8168BF39E98907D.description: Extend understanding of multiplication and division to decimals (1-digit whole number multipliers and 1-digit natural number divisors).

4811898B118945E7947312E54A8A67D4.description: Analyze the simplification of multiple operation expressions for errors in the application of the order of operations.

A7AA35F365B54E10BE57DAE2B47627DF.description: Solve situational questions involving multiple operations, with and without the use of technology.

7EF36BB5FD164D0F94CC613355FC0878.description: Verify, by using technology, whether or not the simplification of an expression involving the use of the order of operations is correct.

84CDD51FD9004013A43CFC77F13AA56A.description: Verify, by using repeated addition and repeated subtraction for multiplication and division respectively, whether or not the simplification of an expression involving the use of the order of operations is correct.

8043A3E2C82541A3A27CDBDCE5B1B7CE.description: Explain, with the support of examples, why there is a need to have a standardized order of operations.

9B3BB8B961304657860F4915F5F24068.description: Demonstrate understanding of the order of operations on whole numbers (excluding exponents) with and without technology.

AE71F93CB5C7435D8422B92D7647D0A8.description: Analyze two whole numbers to determine at least one multiple (greater than both whole numbers) that is common to both

9674877406B64A4290BF3CBDB1894320.description: Analyze two whole numbers for their common factors.

655D77C7FF6F4BFA993434FC60386A66.description: Solve situational questions involving factors, multiples, and prime factors.

82008FC115F54F08A8F7CB66637FB3B6.description: Explain how the composite factors of a whole number can be determined from the prime factors of the whole number and vice versa.

A4E515B22BF04E2EB6EC2C6B1621ECAE.description: Determine the prime factors of a whole number and explain the strategy used to determine the factors.

679B8FC89C40415286352E8B0A77F97D.description: Analyze a whole number to determine if it is a prime number or composite and explain the reasoning.

E4DB83C8F19C4049B3B9DA2D61EBD60B.description: Explain why 0 and 1 are neither prime nor composite

EA13D8053B0445C08E75FBE7CAABDDA2.description: Explain how skip counting and multiples are related.

42D4514AF9D44524A6E983DFFB94F001.description: Represent a set of whole-numbered multiples for a given quantity concretely, pictorially, or symbolically and explain the strategy used to create the representation.

393F1CF5E56D4DE39643DCBEC048C1ED.description: Determine the whole-numbered dimensions of all rectangular regions with a given whole-numbered area and explain how those dimensions are related to the factors of the whole number.

D5F5FEFF0D9345BA9590BAC8F94EDD80.description: Demonstrate understanding of factors and multiples (concretely, pictorially, and symbolically) including: determining factors and multiples of numbers less than 100, relating factors and multiples to multiplication and division and determining and relating prime and composite numbers.

87E11D9C3AC64BF39D15A3DFFE8806F3.description: Estimate the solution to a situational question, without the use of technology, involving operations on quantities larger than one million or smaller than one thousandth and explain the strategies used to determine the estimate.

5864C71CB0A8452E900B42FBA102EFD6.description: Solve situational questions involving operations on quantities larger than one million or smaller than one thousandth (with the use of technology).

43FF2415664A46758823C01D6B4B86AE.description: Explain how the pattern of the place value system (e.g., the repetition of ones, tens, and hundreds), makes it possible to read and write numerals for numbers of any magnitude.

49BB7FDF63874D1985BE4D681422A13E.description: Explain, concretely, pictorially, or orally, how numbers smaller than one thousandth found in mass media and other contexts are related to one thousandth by referencing place value and/or extending concrete or pictorial representations.

A62B0BAACB624897B3405FF5408714B1.description: Change the representation of numbers larger than one million given in decimal and word form to place value form (e.g., $1.8 billion would be changed to $1 800 000 000) and vice versa.

D52D10F1C29940228D8FDD09766F53E6.description: Explain, concretely, pictorially, or orally, how numbers larger than one million found in mass media and other contexts are related to one million by referencing place value and/or extending concrete or pictorial representations.

742D2FE4CF4F4796BEE2E11E20E1E1B5.description: Demonstrate understanding of place value including: greater than one million and less than one thousandth with and without technology

4250314AA45741B28ACC7FAC020B5D7F.description: Number - Goals: Number Sense, Spatial Sense, Logical Thinking, Mathematics as a Human Endeavour
